message: Oh, cool, staying within Google.
Congrats, BTW!
I'm hoping, after I get a handle on Java, to make a few more forays into the JVM languages.
Yea. I'm quite excited about it. Its going to be an opportunity to work with Java, which I haven't really done.
Currently making my way through Effective Java. Its not as expressive as Python, but I must admit that I find the contract of interfaces somewhat comforting.
I've been reading up on Obj-C and thought the same thing about interfaces. I like the idea
So, curious here (re: convore usage), can we switch this topic, or is it best practice to create a new one and move the JVM language discussion there.
Gives a sense of framework and correctness to everything :)
/me may be convincing himself.
Different best practices have emerged for different groups
I'm not keen to say which ones I think are better :)
Thanks. I'm still working at Google. I'm going to be joining a team which is rewriting the software that the startup I joined wrote.
That's such an advantage of working for a bigger company, you can do something completely different and still work for the same employer.
When I think of Java, I think "safe," "verbose," and "powerful".
I keep meaning to look into Clojure, just b/c i want to work with Lisp(-like) things, but haven't had a chance yet
@justinlilly right, i saw that, also up next to the actual topic. Curious, does it drag people with me?
Are you able to talk about it yet?
Really, faster? I suppose it depends on the program, but there are claims that CL can be as fast as C. Does Java get that fast?
Tried messing around with Clojure, but unless you know Java (and its libraries).. you're just using a faster common lisp :)
@asenshi just below the text box, you can post your message as a new topic
just posted a new topic, @asenshi
I don't know that the jvm thing belongs in a django community group, but *shrug*
@justinlilly me either, i was mostly just curious about best practice for us going OT
IMO this is a place for the Django community to talk, and if that happens to be about JVM that's totally cool
